page.title: 10AN HISTORICAL SURVEY.
page.content: The oldest buildings in our block are situated in Rottingdean village. The Black Horse Inn and Whipping Post House are from Tudor times. Other buildings date from Georgian and Victorian days. The Grange in Vicarage Lane and a row of cottages in the High Street are typical Georgian buildings. The Rottingdean Preservation Society keeps an eagle eye on developmenrs. On the timbers of Tudor Close are carved Tudor roses and the date 1530, but these cottages are imitations. The new Roman Catholic Church from 1958 is built from local flint in Norman style. Spread over the downlands are the modern housing estates. The lack of large blocks of flats is obvious.
